text:
Steve was pissed. His stupid car wasn’t working, and his dad had promised to help him. It turned out that his dad’s version of helping was to tell Steve what part he needed to get, and to leave him to figure it out himself from there. So Steve was out here with the hood up, in a t-shirt and an old, beat-up pair of jeans so he wouldn’t ruin his good clothes, with a bandana tied around his forehead to keep the sweat out of his eyes. Because it was hot out. Of course it was hot out. 

Everything Steve Harrington knew about fixing cars had been learned against his will. It was one of the things his dad had used to try to force them to bond. But any time Steve got something the slightest bit wrong, his dad had used it as an excuse to berate him. Not that he needed an excuse, but it was somehow worse. Steve figured his dad was just mad that Steve wasn’t naturally great at the hobbies he wanted him to like. Father-son car “bonding” time was just another way for Steve’s dad to reinforce what a disappointment he was. 

So Steve felt some sense of vindication when, after almost an hour of messing around under the hood, he discovered that his dad was wrong. Sure, his dad hadn’t actually looked at it, but he was still wrong, and Steve was right. And now he had to get to the hardware store to get the parts he needed. Without a working car. Great. 

He wiped his face with the bandana and shoved it in his pocket, then messed with his hair for a minute. It wasn’t going to look good without a shower and a blow dry, but he wasn’t likely to see anyone he knew at the hardware store, so it didn’t really matter. 

It took longer than he expected to find what he needed, and by the time he did, the exhaustion of working on the car, the walk over, and the search had gotten to him. He stood outside the store, holding the plastic bag with his purchase, and took a deep breath, preparing for the walk back. 

“Harrington?” 

Great. Of course. He shouldn’t have jinxed it by assuming he wasn’t going to see anyone he knew. He turned to see Eddie Munson approaching him, eyes narrowed. 

“What are you doing here, Harrington?” 

Steve lifted his plastic bag, a strained smile on his face. He didn’t feel like explaining himself. He and Eddie were friends, but Steve was in a mood. 

“Riiiight,” Eddie said slowly. He leaned back on his heels, looking behind Steve, then faced forward. “Listen, Harrington…” He trailed off, pulling on a strand of his long brown hair. He gave Steve a conspiratorial glance. 

“What?” Steve asked. He wasn’t really in the mood to talk, and he wished Eddie had picked up on that. There was no reason for Eddie to be able to pick up on the nuances of Steve’s moods, though. They didn’t have a whole lot of one-on-one conversations. Usually, when they hung out, there was some sort of social buffer, often in the form of Robin. 

“So…” Eddie said. Steve hadn’t been sure if Eddie was acting weird, because Eddie was a weird guy. But now he was pretty sure Eddie was being weird, because Eddie was one of the most talkative people he knew, next to Robin. And, for some reason, he seemed like he couldn’t get out what he wanted to say. “Look, I’m just asking, okay? Not– I don't mean anything by it. But, uh.” His eyes darted back and forth, then he leaned in close to Steve. Steve had gotten used to that, kind of. The guy had no concept of personal space. “Are you flagging?” Eddie finally finished. 

Steve shook his head slowly, eyes narrowed. He had no idea what that meant. He had no answer. “What?” 

Eddie leaned away from Steve, facing forward again and nodding. “Okay, got it. That answers my question. Carry on.” 

“What the hell are you talking about, Munson?” Steve turned to him, brow furrowed.

Eddie shook his head. “Don’t worry about it.” He looked behind Steve again. “You might want to take that bandana out of your back pocket, though.” 

Steve instinctively, immediately, pulled the bandana out of his pocket and examined it. It was just a plain gray bandana, maybe a little dirty but otherwise normal. “Why? What do you want me to do with it?” 

Eddie put his hands up in a shrug. “I don’t know. Shove it in there deep enough that it’s not sticking out. Put it in your front pocket. Get rid of it. Just don’t leave it like that.” 

“Why?” Steve was bewildered. He had no idea what was going on. “Seriously, what are you talking about?” 

Eddie stared at Steve for a moment, cocking his head. “Do you need a ride?” 

Steve couldn’t even complain about the non-answer because yes, he did very much need a ride. He sighed. “Yeah. Yeah, I do, actually.” 

Eddie gestured dramatically toward the parking lot, a smooth flourish with both arms. “Your chariot awaits.” 

Once they were in Eddie’s car and on their way, Steve had to ask again. It was too weird. “So, uh, what was that about?”

“What was what about?” Eddie glanced over at Steve, his eyes wide and innocent. Steve didn’t buy it for a second. 

“The bandana thing,” Steve said. “The question. You generally being super weird. What’s flagging?” 

“Oh, that,” Eddie said, as though he had completely forgotten it. “It’s a gay thing. People might think you’re gay.”

“Are you fucking with me?” A bandana meant someone was gay? How? Why? 

“Not at all, no.” Eddie sounded serious, but Steve knew that Eddie was capable of a completely deadpan delivery, and Steve had fallen for it a number of times. 

“If you’re trying to make fun of me, you need to get better material, man. Jokes about people being gay are stale. And not cool.” Steve of a few years ago would have been surprised to hear current Steve say that, but he had grown a lot. Not to mention his best friend was gay. 

“I’m pleased to hear you say that, Harrington. But no, I’m not making fun of you. I’m completely serious.”

“How do you even know that?” 

Eddie took one hand off the steering wheel and pulled a black bandana from somewhere, waving it in Steve’s face. 

“Wait.” Steve paused. Considered. “Are you telling me that you’re gay?”

“You catch on quick.” Eddie smiled wryly. 

“Wait,” Steve started. Eddie was not what he pictured when he thought of a gay guy. But there was no one way that a gay person could look, obviously. Steve knew that. He had just never even considered the possibility. He was quickly reframing every time Eddie had invaded his personal space. Not that Eddie was into him or anything, it just felt different knowing that he could be into him. Different how, Steve hadn’t quite decided. He would have to think about that more later. In the meantime, he needed to find a way to end his sentence. “So what, any guy with a bandana is gay?” 

“Not necessarily.” Eddie shrugged one shoulder. “It doesn't have to be a bandana, it can be basically any piece of cloth you want. It depends on the color, the placement, and there are generally context clues. The hardware store isn’t typically a cruising spot, as far as I’m aware.” He grinned, seemingly amused by what he had said. 

A cruising spot? Steve knew what cruising was. Or, he had at least vague knowledge of what cruising was from hearing about the movie Cruising with Al Pacino. Were there cruising spots in Hawkins? That Eddie knew about? Eddie went cruising? That thought made Steve’s stomach feel weird for a reason he couldn’t identify. Another thing to think about more later. 

“So, how does it work? The bandana thing? The colors have different meanings or something?”

“Yeah, they’re about, you know, what kind of stuff people are interested in doing.” 

Steve raised his eyebrows. “Like what?”

“Why don’t you ask one of your other gay friends?”

“What makes you think I have other gay friends?” Steve said quickly. It sounded more defensive than he meant it to. It was just that Eddie knew basically all of his friends. If Steve hinted too much, Eddie would be able to guess. 

“Well, Robin told me you know about her, and she told me you guys have one other gay friend, but she wouldn’t say who he is.”

Robin and Eddie had talked about this? And Robin had told him about Will? 

“He wouldn’t know about this stuff,” Steve said.  Since the Byers had moved back, Will had opened up to Steve and Robin about being gay. Well, first, Robin had made Steve a co-conspirator in a campaign to spend more time just the three of them, so she could casually mention liking girls enough times to make Will feel comfortable. But Will was just a kid. He wouldn’t know the answers to Steve’s questions. Right? “God, I hope he doesn’t know about this stuff.” 

“Why not?” 

“Oh,” Steve said. He realized how weird that must have sounded. Like he had some kind of problem with gay sex, or cruising, or flagging. Which he didn’t, he just really didn’t want to think about those things in relation to Will. “Not like— it’s just because—“ Steve didn’t want to give too much away. Robin hadn’t identified Will, so Steve knew he shouldn’t either. “He’s only fifteen.”

“Like most of your friends.” Eddie nodded. “Say no more.” 

Steve chose to ignore that. “And even if he was old enough, I don’t think he would be interested in that stuff. He’s pretty hung up on one guy. Who’s straight.”

“Ah, yeah,” Eddie said. “Been there.”

They pulled up to Steve’s house then, so Steve didn’t get a chance to ask any more questions. He got out of Eddie’s car, then turned toward Eddie. 

“Thanks for the ride,” he said. “And the tip. About the, uh, bandana.” 

“Any time, Harrington,” Eddie said, grinning again. 

Steve decided not to think about any of the things he had talked about with Eddie, or any of the weird feelings he’d had because of them. That was too much for today. He still had to finish fixing up his car, and after that, all he wanted to do was pass out. 

He shoved the thoughts to the back of his mind, locked them in a box with all the other times he had looked at a guy and felt funny. It wasn’t something he was ready to address. Maybe he wouldn’t ever be ready to address it.

The next morning, Steve took his newly fixed car to pick up Robin for work. It was summer now. Robin had graduated, and was heading to college in the fall, but he at least had the summer with his best friend, working at Family Video. 

He and Robin had a few minutes of small talk, but when there was a lull in the conversation, Steve decided to take a shot. 

“Hey, Rob,” he said, trying his hardest to keep his voice casual. “Do you know what flagging is?”

“Yeah. I mean, kind of? Why do you ask?”

“What is it?”

“It’s like…” she thought for a moment. “It’s a code. For gay people to find casual sex, without straight people knowing what it means. So they take a handkerchief, or a bandana, or whatever, and the color means what you want to do, and the side it’s on means if you’re a top or a bottom. Where did you even hear about that?”

“From Eddie.” He glanced at her. “By the way, why didn’t you tell me Eddie is gay?”

“Uh,” Robin said sarcastically. “Why don’t you tell people I’m gay?”

“That’s different!”

“How is it different?”

She had him there. “Okay, good point.”

“I still don’t understand what happened. Eddie told you he’s gay? And the hanky code came up in conversation somehow?”

Steve sighed. “I had a bandana in my pocket. Eddie asked if I was flagging, I had no idea what he meant, and then he explained. Kind of. That’s why I had to ask you.”

“Oh my god,” Robin said, her voice rising in volume. “Was Eddie hitting on you? Was he, like, propositioning you?”

Wait, was he? “No,” Steve remembered. “Before he asked, he specifically said he was just asking. And he told me the hardware store isn’t a good cruising spot.”

Robin laughed. “What were you even doing at the hardware store?”

“Do you see this car you’re riding in? This well-oiled, perfectly-running machine?” Steve pointed to himself. “I did that. I fixed it, all by myself.”

“Pull over,” Robin said, reaching for the door. “I’m finding another ride.”

“Ha ha,” Steve said flatly. “Very funny.” 

They got to work shortly after and set up to open the store. It would be a little while before the customers started to come in, so Steve decided to ask some more questions while he had the chance. 

“So, the colors. Do you know what they mean?” He asked, trying to sound casual again. 

“Colors?” Robin looked up from the computer, confused. “What colors? What are you talking about?” 

“The—“ Steve waved his hand around. “Bandana thing. Flagging.”

“Oh, are we still on that?” 

“I’m just wondering!”

“What color bandana were you wearing?” 

“Gray.”

“Which pocket was it in?”

“Right.”

“Oh.” Robin nodded. “Hmmmm.”

“So what does that mean?”

“I have no idea.”

“Robin! I thought you said you knew about this stuff!”

“I mean, I know about it vaguely . I don’t use it! I didn’t even realize Eddie used it. What color was his bandana?”

“Black, but I didn’t see what pocket it was in.”

“Oh,” Robin said, raising her eyebrows. “I see.” 

Finally, they were getting somewhere. “What does the black bandana mean?” 

“Also no idea.”

“Robin, come on!” 

“Why do you even need to know all this?”

“I don’t need to,” Steve said. “I’m just curious.”

“Okay.” Robin’s eyebrows were still raised. She looked at Steve in a way that seemed very pointed, but he wasn’t sure what she meant by it. “Curious. Got it.”

“What’s that supposed to mean?”

Steve didn’t get a response, because at that moment the bell on the door jingled. Customers. Back into work mode. 

Later, when there were only a few people around, Steve walked casually over to the action section and found the movie Cruising . He had never actually seen it, but now he was wondering about the plot, and how it connected to the title. And how that connected to what Eddie had told him. 

“Come on,” Steve muttered to himself after reading the description on the back of the box. “His name is Steve? Seriously?” Al Pacino’s character was a cop who had to go undercover to gay S&M clubs. Named Steve. And it seemed to hint that going undercover cruising awakened something in cop Steve, which might cause some sort of conflict with his girlfriend, Nancy . That was too much of a coincidence. He had to watch the movie now, right? He hoped it didn’t awaken anything in him like it did with cop Steve. 

“What are you doing, Harrington?” 

Steve put down the tape and whirled around to find Eddie Munson leaning over him. He was just a little too close, as usual. 

“I’m working,” Steve said. “Putting stuff away. What are you doing here?”

Eddie held up a tape in answer to Steve's question, then looked at the row of movies behind Steve. “Just putting stuff away, huh?” He said. “I thought maybe you were doing some research.” He bit his lip, holding back a smile, and his eyes flicked over to the Cruising tape. 

“Research?” Without turning, Steve reached over to straighten up some tapes. “I’m just fixing these tapes.” He heard one clatter to the ground. “What research would I be doing?”

“Well,” Eddie said, tilting his head and locking eyes with Steve. “You seemed pretty curious the other day.”

“I mean—“ Steve looked away. Eddie’s eye contact was a little too intense for his liking. “I guess.”

“You still want to know?”

“Yeah,” Steve said. Then, afraid he had responded too quickly, he added, “I guess. It doesn’t matter.”

Eddie raised an eyebrow. “So you don’t want to know? What your bandana meant?”

He really, really did, and he didn’t know why it mattered so much. “Sure.” He looked back at Eddie, who was still staring at him intensely, and then looked away again. 

“Sure.” Eddie smirked, nodded once. “I’ll tell you, then.” 

“Okay.” Steve looked at Eddie. He held the eye contact this time, his heart beating fast. “Tell me.”

Eddie leaned in. His long hair touched Steve’s shoulder, and he tilted his head to get his mouth close to Steve’s ear. His voice was barely audible, forcing Steve to tilt his head even closer so he could hear. 

“It means you like to be tied up.” 

Steve felt more than heard what Eddie said. He inhaled sharply, which he hoped Eddie didn’t hear. He also hoped Eddie didn’t see the goosebumps that immediately popped up, trailing down from Steve’s neck, where he still felt Eddie’s breath. 

Eddie leaned away, grinning, and took a step back. He spoke in a normal tone of voice. “See you around, Harrington.” 

Shit. He didn’t even need the fucking movie to awaken something in him. He was in trouble. 

 

Steve and Robin were going to a party at the Byers house. He supposed he should call it the Byers-Hopper house, because the pair were officially cohabiting. This weekend, though, Joyce and Hopper were out of town, and the Byers boys were having a party. Jonathan and Will were good boys though, so they had actually managed to get permission for this party, on the conditions that it stayed small, and that there would be no underage drinking. Steve hoped that second rule wasn’t going to be followed too stringently. He had barely hung out with Nancy while Jonathan was there, at least not when they weren't fighting monsters, and the thought made him nervous. 

When Steve and Robin arrived, there were already a few cars parked outside of the Byers’ new house. Some looked familiar, but he couldn’t quite place them. Despite his amazing feat of repair work the previous week, Steve still didn’t give a shit about cars. 

Steve knocked, and was surprised when the door was opened by Jonathan’s long-haired stoner friend. 

“Hey!” Steve said, plastering a smile on his face. “It’s…you!

“Hey yourself, man!” Jonathan’s friend said, wrapping Steve in a hug that went on just a little bit too long for someone whose name Steve couldn’t even remember. 

He rounded on Robin next, but she managed to dodge. “Hey Argyle! Good to see you!” Argyle . Steve wasn’t sure how he had forgotten that name; it was genuinely one of the weirdest things about his spring break. Who named their kid Argyle? “You’re visiting?” Robin asked. 

“Yeah, dude, I just flew in. Had to see the new digs, see all of you lovely people, hang out in Hawkins for a while.” 

“Great,” Robin said. “Where are–” She peered around Argyle and into the house. 

“Oh, yeah, come on in. Everyone’s out in the yard.” Argyle ushered them through the living room and out to the back yard.

Steve scanned the yard, scoping out the party. Dustin and Will were talking nearby. Couples were coupled up– Max and Lucas, El and Mike, Nancy and Jonathan. Ugh. There was music playing from a small boombox, and next to it sat Eddie, looking through a pile of tapes. 

Steve and Robin walked over to Eddie. “Anything good?” Steve asked, gesturing toward the cassettes. 

“For a certain value of good,” Eddie said. “Not my thing, but not bad.” He put down the last tape and looked up at Robin and Steve. “Where have you two been?”  

“Yeah, I can’t believe we’d be the last ones to arrive at a sober party full of mostly high school sophomores.” 

“The sophomores are sober, but we don’t have to be.” Eddie stood. “I’m gonna get a beer, you guys want one?” 

“I thought there was no underage drinking allowed.” 

“I’m twenty-one.” 

“Wait, you were supposed to graduate the year before me, right?” Steve did some quick math in his head. “So you should only be a year older than me. I’m nineteen.” 

“Well, apparently I’m two years older.” 

“Why?”

“Why?” Eddie looked incredulous. “Because I was born two years before you. It really doesn’t matter, Harrington. Do you want a beer or not?” 

“Yeah,” Steve said. He was glad that someone had brought drinks, though surprised that Jonathan would risk Hopper’s wrath. 

“Robin?” Eddie asked. 

“Sure,” she said, avoiding Steve’s surprised glance. 

Eddie walked off to get the drinks. 

“You’re drinking?” Steve asked Robin. “You never drink at parties.” 

“Not never ,” she said. “Just…rarely. I need to calm my nerves.”

“What are you nervous about? There are like six people here.”

“There are twelve,” Robin corrected. “And hopefully Vickie will be the thirteenth.” 

“What? You invited Vickie?”

“Yeah. I told you I was going to.”

“No, you didn’t.” Steve was sure he would have remembered that. 

“Yes, I did,” Robin insisted. “You just forgot.” 

“You didn’t tell me,” Steve said. “Because if you had told me, I wouldn’t have wanted to come be a third wheel. And if I didn’t come, you wouldn’t have a ride.” His eyes widened as it dawned on him. “You tricked me!”

Robin looked guilty. 

“I can’t believe you tricked me so you could bring a date!”

“It’s not a date.”

“Of course it’s a date. You like her, don’t you?”

“Shhh.” Robin looked around to make sure no one was listening. “Yeah, but if it’s a date, she doesn’t know about it.”

“Fine, it’s not technically a date. But I’m still going to be majorly third wheeling. Who am I supposed to hang out with when everyone’s all paired off?”

“Not everyone’s paired off. You’ve got Dustin and Will.” She pointed at them. “Argyle.” A dark haired girl walked out of the house and greeted Argyle with a kiss. “Okay, maybe not Argyle. But there’s Eddie,” she finished, gesturing to Eddie as he reappeared in front of them. 

“What about me?” He asked, handing them their beers. Steve opened his and took a swig. 

“Steve was saying he wouldn’t have anyone to hang out with if I was busy talking to Vickie.”

“You wound me, Harrington.” Eddie put a hand over his heart, staggering backward theatrically. “Am I not good enough company for you?” 

“No,” Steve said quickly. “It’s not that. It’s just—she tricked me.” 

“It was for love,” Eddie said mock-seriously. “She had to do it. I’m sorry I didn’t try to stop her. I thought the end justified the means.” 

“Wait, did you know about this?” Did Robin really tell Eddie about her date before Steve?

Eddie put his hands up in a gesture of surrender. “I must admit,” he said in the same dramatic tone. “I did.”  

“You two were conspiring against me. I can’t believe it.” 

“Maybe I was just conspiring to get you alone,” Eddie said. His head was tilted down and he looked up at Steve through his eyelashes. Steve couldn’t tell if this was part of the bit, if he was still joking around. He didn’t want to respond to it without knowing, so he killed some time by taking a long drink of his beer, and then decided to ignore it. 

“You owe me big time,” he said to Robin. “I’m serious.”

“But?” Eddie was half-smiling. Steve wondered if he knew what was coming. If he did, and he was smiling, that was a good thing, right?

“But it doesn’t— I don’t feel casual about it anymore.” Steve looked into Eddie’s eyes, trying to figure out what he might be thinking as Steve spoke. “I don’t know if I ever really did, not completely. But now I feel… serious. Really serious. About you.”

“What are you talking about, Steve?” Eddie looked away, licking his lips. 

Steve’s heart sank. Eddie didn’t sound happy. Steve had really thought this was going to go well. “I’m saying I have feelings for you.” 

“Feelings?” Eddie said it with what sounded almost like a laugh, but he didn’t look like he was laughing. “Man, I can’t do shit with that.” 

Steve felt like he had been punched. “What does that mean?”

Eddie took a step back and turned away from Steve. “I can’t do shit with your feelings, Steve! I can’t— I can’t deal with that!” 

“What?” This wasn’t how Steve had pictured this. He had been so sure. “I thought— I kind of thought you felt the same way.” 

“Of course I do. You’re Steve fucking Harrington, everyone is in love with you.” He didn’t look at Steve when he said it. 

“Are you being sarcastic?” Steve asked weakly. It would be a really shitty thing to be sarcastic about it, but if he was serious, why did he sound so angry? 

“I wish.” Eddie fidgeted with his rings, avoiding Steve’s gaze. “Fuck.”

“I don’t understand.” So Eddie had feelings for him. Maybe was even in love with him. But he was upset that Steve felt the same way? “What’s the problem?”

“Me.” Eddie gestured at himself with both hands. “I’m the problem!” 

“You’re- you’re not a problem, Eddie.”

“Yes, I am.” He pressed the heels of his hands to his eyes and then looked at Steve again. “This is my fault. I guess I was having too much fun playing at being in a relationship.”

“I’m not playing, Eddie. I want to be in an actual relationship with you.” 

“No.” Eddie shook his head. “I should never have let it go this far. This whole thing was a mistake.” 

“What, is that why you left last night? It got too real for you?” Steve hadn’t really believed Eddie’s excuse, but he had given him the benefit of the doubt. Had Eddie just been messing around, the whole time? It really hadn't felt like it. 

“It wasn’t supposed to go like this.” Eddie sounded frantic. “You weren’t supposed to have feelings for me, Steve. You were supposed to fuck around for a while, get it out of your system. Then you’d go find some girl, get married, have kids, have a normal life.” 

“I don’t want that. I want to be with you.” 

“Steve. You don’t know what you’re talking about. You don’t know what that life would be like. Do you really want to hide that from everyone? What if your parents found out?” 

“Fuck my parents,” Steve said. “I don’t even want to talk to them once I move out. None of that matters.” 

Steve knew what Eddie was saying. Obviously they wouldn’t be able to be open about their relationship, but Steve had no illusions about that. They would tell Robin, maybe a few other friends, people they trusted. To everyone else, they’d just be…close friends. Maybe roommates. They could get a two-bedroom apartment; nobody would ask questions. 

“Steve, don’t do this,” he said firmly. “Just don’t. You can’t throw your life away like that. Not for me.”

Steve’s mouth opened, but he couldn’t find any words that made sense. “What are you talking about?” he finally got out. 

“This isn’t— I can’t do this, Steve. We can’t do this.” 

“Why not?” Steve didn’t get it. If he felt the same way, why was he so adamant that they couldn’t be together?

Eddie rubbed the back of his neck. “Do you remember when you asked me if I’ve ever been in love?” 

“Yeah,” Steve said. He had been pretty drunk at the time, but he hadn’t forgotten that conversation. 

“When you asked me that…” Eddie pushed his hand into his hair, resting his palm on his forehead. “I had never even considered that. It was never on the table. I knew it would never happen.”

“What? Why?” Steve found that hard to believe. Yeah, it would be hard growing up gay in Hawkins, but Eddie could have met someone here. Or he could have moved somewhere better, somewhere gay people didn’t have to hide. Or, at the very least, he could have imagined doing those things.

“It’s just not for people like me.” 

Steve furrowed his brow, confused. “Lots of gay people are in love, Eddie. There are gay people out there saying they want to get married.”

“You don’t get it. I’m not talking about that. I’m–” Eddie’s eyes darted around, looking everywhere except at Steve. “I’m damaged goods, Steve. I can’t let you do this. It’s not worth it.”

“You’re not damaged goods .” What did that even mean? “Jesus, Eddie.”  

Eddie leaned his head back, biting his lips. He closed his eyes for a second, took a deep breath, then opened them. “You know why I live with my uncle?” Eddie waited a moment, staring intensely at Steve. 

Did he want an answer to that? Steve shook his head, almost imperceptibly. 

“My parents figured out that I was gay in middle school,” Eddie said.  “I was just a kid. I wasn’t even– I don’t know. There were enough clues and I wasn’t a good liar.” He looked down for a second, took another deep breath and looked at Steve again. “It’s not like they were ever great parents. Yeah, my dad hit me before then. But not like this. He beat the shit out of me so bad —“ Eddie stabbed the air with his hand for emphasis. “That the state took me away from him. Do you know how bad it has to be for them to do that?” Eddie didn’t look sad, or angry. He just looked tired. “I cannot emphasize enough how much the state of Indiana does not give a shit about abused gay kids, Steve. He really fucked me up. I could have died.” 

“Eddie…” Steve reached out, trying to take his hand, but Eddie pulled it away. Steve wanted to cry, or maybe scream. He couldn’t believe Eddie wasn’t crying and screaming now, or all the time, to have gone through that. Steve knew a lot of shitty dads, including his own, but this was different. How could someone do that to their own kid? 

“He broke…a lot of stuff.” Eddie put a hand to his face. “My jaw was wired shut for like three months. I missed so much school I had to repeat the year. And the whole time I was just waiting on the judge to decide whether my parents should have to take me back. God knows they didn’t want me.”

It was horrible. It was the worst thing Steve had ever heard. But he still didn’t understand what it had to do with Steve’s feelings for Eddie. 

“So my uncle took me. I don’t even know why. We’ve never talked about it. None of it.” Eddie’s eyes looked hollow. “And then in high school, I– I’ve done a lot of things I’m not proud of. You wouldn’t be, either. You wouldn’t be doing this right now if you knew all of it.” 

“Eddie, that’s—“

Eddie cut him off. “It’s shit, Steve. Is that really what you want? My life is shit. I’m shit.”

Steve felt transported back to the night that Nancy had proclaimed everything bullshit, the night he knew their relationship was over. That’s what Eddie was doing. He was ending things. But it was different from when Nancy had done it. It was wrong. Eddie wasn’t ending it because of how he felt about Steve, he was ending it because of how he felt about himself. 

“Eddie. You’re not shit. You don’t deserve any of that.” 

“Well, it’s what I’ve got. So you should go find something else. Please .” He said the last word with a desperation that Steve had never heard from him before. He stared at Steve for a moment and then started toward the door. 

“Eddie!” Steve felt himself getting louder, which he knew wouldn’t help, but he couldn’t stop. He felt like he was trying to be heard from across a crowded room, like if he could just get Eddie to hear him , he could get through to him. He could make it okay. “Will you just listen to me for a second?” 

Eddie reached the door, but he turned back, his hand still on the knob. Steve felt a burst of hope. 

“Don’t call me, okay?”

Steve’s heart sank again. “What, like, ever?”

“I don’t know, man.” Steve couldn’t see Eddie’s face, but he heard his voice start to break. “Maybe.”

Steve didn’t know what to do after Eddie left. He just went to his room, put on his Black Sabbath tape, and cried. 

Steve had never been much of a crier. It didn’t come easily. Each sob was physically painful, tearing through his chest. By the time the tape was over, he felt numb and exhausted. He couldn’t cry anymore. His body couldn’t handle it. 

He went downstairs to the kitchen. Eddie’s note was still on the counter. Steve stared at it for a moment, trying to figure out what Eddie had written at the bottom and then torn off. Maybe it didn’t matter. Maybe it was just his name. Steve wished, if it had been his name, that he had left it there. Then at least Steve would have that. Now he had nothing. He crumpled up the paper and threw it away. 

He picked up the phone, listened to the dial tone for a long moment, then called Robin. 

“Hey,” he said when she answered. 

“Steve? What’s going on?” She must have heard in his voice that something was wrong. Or maybe she was just surprised to hear from him so soon. 

“You were wrong.” That wasn’t fair. This wasn’t Robin’s fault. “We were both wrong.” 

“What do you mean? He doesn’t…” she trailed off. 

“He dumped me. Or, I guess,” Steve said with a laugh that was completely devoid of humor. “I guess he didn’t dump me, because we were never actually together.” 

“I don’t understand.” 

“Me neither.” Steve couldn’t talk anymore. He hung up the phone. 

After a few seconds, the phone started ringing. Steve unplugged it. 

Steve didn’t talk to anyone for a couple of days. He just sat in his room, feeling numb. He didn’t talk to his parents when they got home. He called in sick to work. He felt bad that Robin would have to get another ride, but he couldn’t face her. He couldn’t face anyone. 

After a while, he couldn’t stand being in his room anymore. He took to wandering around town, avoiding places where he might see anyone he knew. 

He was at a park, just walking around, trying to find an area away from all the people. Eventually he found a secluded bench, but someone was already sitting on it. It was Will. 

“Hey, what are you doing here?” Steve asked. He had barely said anything for days, and his voice felt rusty from disuse. “Can I sit?” 

“Sure,” Will said. “Just came here to think.”

“Yeah, me too.” That wasn’t exactly true. Steve was mostly trying to avoid thinking right now. Thinking would make him feel sad, and angry. Right now he just felt nothing, which was better. “What are you thinking about?”

“I don’t know.” Will looked off into the distance. “I’m thinking about telling Dustin and Lucas that…you know. I’m gay. I’m just worried about how they’ll react.”

“I think they’ll be okay.” Dustin and Lucas were good kids. Steve had to believe they would be good about this. “It might take them a little while to, I don’t know, adjust. But you guys are best friends. That’s not gonna change that easily.” 

“I guess so.” Will didn’t sound convinced.

“What brought that on?” 

“Telling people has been pretty okay so far.” Steve knew that he and Robin knew, and Jonathan and Mike. He wasn’t sure if Will had told anyone else. “Every time I do, I feel a little better. I know that not everyone is going to be that accepting. But it’s just so exhausting, hiding a part of myself all the time.” 

“Yeah, I know what you mean.” Steve had been hiding his sexuality, his relationship with Eddie, and his true feelings for Eddie. The last one he had even been hiding from himself, somehow. “I’ve been meaning to tell you, actually. I would have told you when you told me, but I hadn’t realized it yet.”

Will looked at him. “You’re gay?” 

“Bisexual. You don’t sound surprised.”

“No. I mean, I would have been, but— is there something going on between you and Eddie?”

“Yeah,” Steve said. So Will’s weird looks had been because he suspected. “Well. There was.” 

“You guys broke up?”

“I guess. We weren’t even really dating. Not officially, at least.”

“What happened?”

Steve didn’t know where to begin. It was hard to tell this story without including details that he definitely didn’t want to share with Will. “We started hanging out a lot. We got really close. It got…” he searched for a word. 

“Romantic?” Will offered.

“Yeah.” Sure, Steve would go with that. It wasn’t even wrong. It was true that things had gotten sexual before they got romantic, but in retrospect it really didn’t take long for it to be both. “But we kept saying we were just friends. Not just to other people. To each other, and to ourselves. It took me a stupidly long amount of time to realize how I really felt about him. But I did realize, and I told him.” 

“He didn’t feel the same way?” 

Steve shook his head. “That’s the thing. He did. He does.”

“So what’s the problem?”

Steve let out a dry laugh. “Yeah, I asked him the same thing. He just doesn’t think we should be together.” 

“Why not?” 

“I don’t know. I don’t get it. He kept saying I deserved better, stuff like that. Like he wasn’t good enough for me. Or good enough for anyone to care about him. He’s been through a lot, but–”

“His dad was abusive.” 

“He told you that?” Steve was surprised. 

Will shrugged. “Mostly hinted, but I got the picture.” 

“Probably not the whole picture. Trust me, abusive doesn’t even begin to cover it. He was… a monster.” Steve knew monsters. He had seen monsters. Eddie’s dad was definitely up there in the rankings of worst monsters he’d heard of. 

Will looked down at his hands, which were folded in his lap. “It can really make you feel worthless,” he said after a moment. “Like, if your own dad doesn’t love you, how could anyone? Why should they?” 

“Will…” Steve had never known Will’s dad, but he had heard stories. 

“I have a lot of people who care about me. I know I do. My mom, Jonathan. All of my friends. But I still sometimes think…” He was still staring at his hands, not looking at Steve. “Someday they’re all going to realize.” 

“Realize what?” 

“That I’m not worth it. That I deserved all the bad stuff that happened to me.” 

“Will, of course you didn’t.” Steve looked at him, trying to catch his eye, but he was still looking down. “Of course you’re worth it.” 

“I know,” Will said. “I know. But I’ve had my mom and Jonathan there telling me that my whole life, and I still feel like that sometimes.” He turned to Steve. “Who did Eddie have?” 

Steve shook his head. No one. When Eddie was growing up, he didn’t have anyone telling him that he was loved, that he was worthy. “He has me, now.” 

“But he doesn’t believe it.” 

“He said if I knew everything in his past, I wouldn’t care about him like that.” 

“Do you know what he was talking about? The stuff in his past?” 

“I’ve got some idea.” Eddie had said his dad hit him, even before the worst time. And that his parents didn’t even want him after they found out he was gay. Those were the things that made Eddie feel like he was worthless. But there was also the stuff Eddie had said he wasn’t proud of. Steve didn’t know what that was. Sex? Drugs? Did it matter? “Nothing that would make me stop loving him.” 

“Did you tell him that?” Will asked, looking at Steve with raised eyebrows. 

“What, that his past doesn’t matter or that I love him?” It felt good to say it out loud. It felt right. 

“Both.” 

“I didn’t really get a chance to say the love part. He stopped me as soon as I said I had feelings for him. But I told him, you know, he’s not damaged. ” 

“But he is, though.” Will’s tone was matter-of-fact, like it was obvious.

“Don’t say that.” 

“It’s true. What he’s been through left damage. Scars. I mean, physical, mental, I don’t know. But he’s damaged. So am I. You probably are, too. I don’t mean it as an insult. It’s just what happens when you go through stuff like that.” 

Steve didn’t think he was damaged. But if he wasn’t damaged by his parents, why had he felt so guilty about not getting into college when he didn’t even want to go? If he wasn’t damaged by the Upside Down, why did he still have nightmares about monsters and look around every room he entered to see what he might be able to use as a weapon? Eddie had said he wanted Steve to have a normal life, but how was he supposed to do that? The things he had been through made that impossible. 

Will was right. It might not sound nice, but it was true. They were all damaged. All of Hawkins probably was, after the last few years. 

“So what am I supposed to say?” Steve asked. “You are damaged, and I love you anyway?” 

“Something like that,” Will said. “Maybe not those exact words.” 

“You think that will work?” 

“Work how? It’s not going to fix him. It’s not going to erase what happened to him.” 

“I don’t need it to. I don’t want it to. I just want to be there for him, and show him that he’s worth it. Every day. So maybe someday he’ll start to believe it.” 

Will smiled. “Tell him that.” 

“When did you get so…” 

“Wise?” Will finished, a half-smile on his face. 

Steve remembered their D&D session and laughed. “Okay, Will the Wise. Come here, man.” Steve pulled him into a hug. He couldn’t believe he was getting relationship advice from one of the kids. They were really growing up.

The day after his talk with Will, Steve drove to the trailer park. He had to. He couldn’t leave all those things unsaid. He couldn’t live with himself if he didn’t at least try. 

He knocked on the door, and Eddie answered. Steve had thought he might be angry, might even slam the door in Steve’s face, but he just looked sad. 

“What are you doing here, Steve?” He spoke in a quiet monotone. 

“I need to talk to you.” 

“We talked.” 

“I didn’t get to say everything I needed to say.” 

“I heard enough. Please, Steve. Just move on.” 

“I can’t.” Steve tried to stay calm, but he could hear the desperation in his voice. “Just give me five minutes, Eddie. Please. If you don’t like what I have to say, I’ll leave.” 

Eddie stared at him for a moment, his expression blank, then stepped out of the doorway and walked inside. Steve followed, closing the door behind him.

Steve took a deep breath, but Eddie spoke before he had the chance. 

“Steve, before you say whatever you think you want to say, just think about it for a second, okay? This doesn’t make sense. We don’t make sense. This isn’t how it’s supposed to be for you. What would your friends from high school think if they knew you were hanging around the trailer park with some drug dealing loser faggot?” The word made Steve flinch. “Let alone fucking him?”

“Eddie, why the hell would I care what anyone from high school thinks? You know all the people who matter to me. They’re your friends too. They love you.”

“Don’t say that.”

“Why not? It’s true. Dustin and Mike idolize you.”

“I really wish you wouldn’t—“ He winced, like something had stung him. “They shouldn’t. They don’t know anything about me. Not really. If they knew everything—“

“They would still love you.” 

“No.” Eddie shook his head. “No one would love me if they knew everything about me. And they really shouldn’t.” 

“I accept that challenge.”

“I’m not joking, Steve.”

“Neither am I. I love you, Eddie.” There. It was out. Whatever came of it, at least he had gotten it out.

“Don’t say that, Steve. You don’t know what you’re signing up for with that.” 

“Yes, I do. I know you’ve been through some really serious shit, which probably fucked you up in ways that I don’t fully understand—”

“You can’t understand.” His voice was strained.

“Eddie, I’ve been through shit, too! Some of it with you, remember? I can definitely understand some of it, okay? And the rest— I want to try. I want to understand everything. Please, Eddie. Just let me try.”

Eddie just shook his head. Steve thought he saw tears in his eyes, but Eddie looked away quickly when he saw Steve looking. 

“I love you, Eddie. The good parts, the bad parts, the scary parts. I love you. What you’ve been through, or what you’ve done, or whatever it is that makes you feel like no one should love you– I don’t care about all that.” He shook his head. That wasn’t right. He thought about his conversation with Will. “No, I do care about it. I care a lot. I’m sorry you went through it, but I’m not ignoring it, okay? I’m not pretending it doesn’t exist. I know you’re not perfect, but I’m not asking you to be. I know who you are. I love you.” 

“Steve…” He sounded choked up, and the tears that Steve had seen before were definitely there. Eddie wiped his eyes quickly, turning his head away. 

“Do you love me, Eddie? If you really don’t, I’ll leave, I swear. I know you’re scared, and you think you’re not worth it, but just let me– please. I want to show you that you are.” 

“Steve.” Eddie looked down at his hands, which were twisting together nervously, then up at Steve. His eyes were wide. “Are you sure?” 

“Yes.” Steve stepped closer to Eddie. “Yes, I’m sure. Probably the most sure I’ve ever been about anything.” 

Eddie still looked uncertain, his brow furrowed. “Okay. Yeah.” He nodded. 

Steve moved forward, taking Eddie’s face in his hands. “Yeah?”

“Yeah.” It was like a weight had been lifted. Eddie’s expression cleared, and he let out a shaky laugh. “Yeah, I love you, Steve.” 

As soon as Eddie said it, Steve leaned forward to kiss him. Steve wanted Eddie to know how he felt, all of the love and affection and care he had, and he tried to put all of that into one kiss. He wasn’t sure if he accomplished that, but he hoped there were many more kisses in the future that he could try with. He knew there were. 

When they broke apart, Steve still held Eddie’s face. “I love you,” he said again. “I love you.” He felt like he couldn't say it enough times.

Eddie smiled. “I love you too.” 

“Excuse me,” a voice said from behind them. “Could you boys step to the side a bit? Just, it’s the only walkway.” 

Eddie jumped back, away from Steve. “Uncle Wayne! It’s not— I’m not—“ He looked at Steve, pleadingly, but Steve couldn’t see a way out of this either. There was really no explanation other than the truth. 

“It’s fine, Eddie.” Wayne’s voice was even. He didn’t seem angry about what he had seen, or really even surprised. “Just trying to get to my room.” 

“But, um.” Eddie looked nervously toward Steve again, and then back at his uncle. “You’re not—“ 

“Did you think I didn’t know, Eddie?” Wayne asked. “You boys are not as sneaky as you think you are. Besides, I always knew about you, Eddie. Did you think I didn’t know why that good-for-nothing brother of mine did that to you? Why I took you in? And I loved you anyway, didn’t I?” He paused, looking at Eddie for a long moment. “I knew it wouldn’t be easy for you. But all I wanted was for you to be happy. For my kid to be happy. So if this—” he looked Steve up and down “— Steve Harrington makes you happy? Well.” He threw up his hands, a small smile on his face. “Mazel tov. Don’t fuck on the couch.” He walked past them toward his bedroom. Steve and Eddie watched him in disbelief. 

“Well,” Eddie said after a moment, gesturing toward his own bedroom. “You heard the man.” 

They fell onto Eddie’s bed, holding each other. They kissed a little, shed a few more tears. But mostly they just talked. They talked more honestly about their feelings than they ever had. Steve felt so relieved to open up to Eddie, and to have him do the same. He was happier than he had been in a very long time. 

“I didn’t know that my uncle knew. I figured he never would have taken me if he’d known.” 

“I can’t believe he never talked to you about it.” 

“We don’t talk a lot. That might have been the most words he’s ever said to me at once. I didn’t even realize he cared that much.” 

“He loves you.” 

“Yeah.” Eddie looked bewildered. “I think I’ve heard those words more today than I ever have in my life.” 

That broke Steve’s heart a little, but he smiled at Eddie anyway. “Well, get used to it. Because I love you.” 

“When did you know?” Eddie asked. He looked at Steve with gentle curiosity. “That you were…in love with me and shit.” He made his voice light. He was clearly still having trouble being serious about the topic. That was okay with Steve. The fact that they were even having this conversation was enough for him, considering the drama of the past few days. 

“I think it happened gradually,” Steve said. “There were clues that I probably should have seen sooner. But when I was sure—really sure? It was that night. When you left.” 

“I’m sorry, Steve.” Eddie met Steve’s eyes. “I should never have left like that. I just wasn’t ready to face it.” He paused. Sighed. “You were right. It got too real. I’d never done that with anyone before.”

“Done what?” He found it hard to believe that anything they’d done, that night or any other, was completely new to Eddie. 

“Come on, don’t make me say it.” 

“You’re going to have to say it, because I have no idea what you’re talking about.”

“I’d never… made love. ” He cringed. “Okay, that was too corny. Forget I said that.”

“No,” Steve said, shaking his head and smiling. It was corny, but he knew exactly what Eddie meant. “I’ll never forget it.” 

Eddie smiled back, a little reluctantly. 

“When did you know?” Steve asked. 

“Hmm…” Eddie made exaggerated thinking noises. “Definitely when you took a bite out of that demobat.” 

“Fuck off.” 

“No, I’m serious,” Eddie said. “That was…” he trailed off, looking wistful. “The hottest thing I’d ever seen. I knew it was either love or extreme horniness. Turns out it was both.”

“You’re a freak,” Steve said, with affection.

“Yeah, but you love me for it.” 

Steve leaned in for a kiss. “Yeah, I do.”

“God, you guys have more hair products than Nancy,” Robin said, her voice muffled behind the bathroom door. 

“But you can’t argue with the results!” Steve said. 

Eddie, sitting next to Steve on the bed, turned toward him with a tender smile. He reached out to brush Steve’s cheek and tuck a lock of hair behind his ear. “I look better than you,” he said softly. 

Robin came out of the bathroom. “So, this is Steve’s room? And the other one is Eddie’s? Is that what we’re saying? I just want to make sure we have our stories straight.” She tilted her head. “So to speak.” 

Steve and Eddie looked at each other. 

“I don’t know, Rob,” Steve said. “We were kind of thinking of…not doing that. Not with them.” 

“So, what? This is a coming out party as well as a housewarming?” 

Steve shrugged. “Maybe? What do you think?” 

“I think they’re your best friends. Our best friends. And we’ve been through so much shit together that I can’t imagine anything changing that.” 

“That’s kind of what we were hoping,” Steve said. 

There was a knock at the door, and the three of them rushed to it together. Robin looked through the peephole. 

“Who is it?” Steve asked. 

“Um.” Robin hesitated. “Everybody?”

“What do you mean? How can it be everybody?” Steve pushed her aside and looked. Nancy, Jonathan, Mike, El, Will, Lucas, Max, Dustin, and Vickie were all standing there. “How did they all get here at exactly the same time?” This was ridiculous. There was no way they had all come together. Steve had anticipated doing this slowly, gradually. One or two people at a time. Maybe dropping a few subtle hints first. So much for that plan. 

Eddie held out his hand. “Are we doing this, Harrington?” 

Steve put his hand in Eddie’s. “Yeah,” he said. “Yeah, we’re doing this.” He took a deep breath and opened the door.
